hero.title: The invisible backend
hero.subtitle: Documenting and modernizing a legacy O.R. system

challenge.heading: THE CHALLENGE
challenge.text: A critical operating room integration system (controlling cameras and displays during surgery) required a full backend code rewrite. However, zero documentation existed, and the codebase was too fragile to touch without a visual reference.

myRole.heading: MY ROLE
myRole.text: I was tasked with reconstructing the system's entire UI and logic from scratch to provide the engineering team with a "Source of Truth," followed by designing a new, complex Admin Configuration Panel.

outcome.heading: THE OUTCOME
outcome.text: I delivered a pixel-perfect functional replica of the system (reverse-engineered from video footage) and a new, error-proof admin interface, enabling the development team to successfully refactor the platform.

phase1.title: Phase 1 - the excavation (reverse engineering)
phase1.frictionText: The developers needed to modernize the tech stack, but they didn't know the full scope of the existing UI states. There was no access to the live environmentâ€”only a marketing video and sales demos.
phase1.solutionIntro: I conducted a frame-by-frame visual audit of the available footage to map the system.
phase1.reconstructionText: I built a comprehensive Figma library that mirrored the live system 1:1.
phase1.valueText: This turned "guesswork" into a documented specification. Developers used my Figma files as the blueprint for the rewrite, ensuring no feature was lost in the migration.

phase2.title: Phase 2 - the admin panel (designing for technicians)
phase2.challengeText: I was tasked with designing a new "Settings & Configuration" panel for hospital technicians. This interface was data-dense and technically complex.
phase2.uxStrategyIntro: Technicians working in O.R. environments cannot afford mistakes. I applied error prevention principles (Nielsen's Heuristics) to the form design:
phase2.constraintText: I replaced open text inputs with sliders and steppers for numerical values.
phase2.whyText: This physically prevented users from entering invalid data (e.g., entering "200" for a value capped at "100"), reducing configuration errors and support calls.

phase3.title: Phase 3 - the handoff and micro-interactions as specs
phase3.intro: Since this was a hardware-integrated system, timing mattered.
phase3.precisionSpecsText: I didn't just hand off static screens. I defined the logic of micro-interactions (e.g.,
phase3.precisionSpecsExample: "The status indicator must blink at 500ms intervals for 3 seconds upon connection failure"
phase3.collaborationText: This level of detail bridged the gap between Design and Engineering, removing ambiguity for the developers implementing the hardware feedback loops.
